description.p: If you have proficiency with the hurdy-gurdy, you can add your proficiency bonus to any ability checks you make to play music with the instrument. A bard can use a musical instrument as a spellcasting focus.
These supplies are a type of artisan’s tools that include a basic fishing pole and a tackle box with a simple line, hooks, bait, bobbers, and lures.
This reinforced fishing pole is of much higher quality than a basic pole. It grants a +3 bonus to your overall fishing score (after any multipliers).
This mithril-infused line enables you to reel in tougher fish. It grants a +1 bonus to your overall fishing score (after any multipliers).
These vibrant lures catch the eye of more elusive fish. They grant a +1 bonus to your overall fishing score (after any multipliers).

You gain this feat after spending 30 or more in-game days fishing. You roll one additional d6 when you fish (total of 6d6). In addition, you can choose to gain a + 10 bonus to your overall fishing score (after any multipliers) whenever you fish.

You gain this feat after spending 100 or more in-game days fishing. You roll one additional d6 when you fish (total of 7d6). In addition, you can choose to gain a + 10 bonus to your overall fishing score (after any multipliers) whenever you fish. This ability can be used along with the bonus granted from Angler.

A sheet of incenae paper, usually bundled in cotton strings. Although the quality of these parchments aren't very high, depending on the ritual they may be treated with perfumes or have metals embedded into them.
Sheets of these are often burnt as offerings as part of Kara-Turan traditions which regard the dead.

A stack of 60 sheets of incenae paper, usually bundled in cotton strings. Although the quality of these parchments aren't very high, depending on the ritual they may be treated with perfumes or have metals embedded into them.
Sheets of these are often burnt as offerings as part of Kara-Turan traditions which regard the dead.

A bolt of perfumed incense cloth. These fabrics are typically 6in in diameter and made of of cotton or other absorbent materials to better soak the perfume it is treated in. Oftentimes, text is inked into the cloth right before use or before it is sold.
These are typically used in Multhorandi funerary rites to prepare bodies for burial, but find use as apparel by warriors, nobles and spellweavers alike.
A stick treated with fragrant oils. They are usually made from dense woods which burn slowly.
These are burnt in religious rites and come in a variety of fragrances depending on the culture and occasion.
